I guess it's because, in my mind, there's a huge whooping difference
between a skeleton or ghost that's summoned on the spot and one that's
either bought or placed there at the beginning of a scenario.

Generally, I don't hire skeletons and/or ghosts, but I decided to do
so in this case.  I went through the built-in scenarios twice, played
through almost all of Telvido's 50 in Slaughter,  . . and I'm
struggling through my own set.  I keep spending all my money on
strength.  I'm afraid of spending much more on constitution or my team
becomes even more vulvernable than they already are.

If it wasn't for my ghost, though, I couldn't have gotten my archer
(or any other character in team for that matter) (why pick him: 
explosion attack - wipe out lots of faeries at once - and have a
character who can do a fairly decent job of removing the extra trees)
through Scenario 122 or Yet Even More Hedges without him dying.

[That's a lesson learned: don't mix mazes using trees as walls with
either high powered druids or elves.]

[Gotta move remodeling "Archer Encampment" up in my priority list.] 
The changes I made to Scenario 121 or Even More Hedges made it a lot
more playable. (widening the diagonal rows)

What I wouldn't give for basic intelligence upgrades:

1)instead of a ghost yelling for help, it uses the scare attack and
heads for the nearest friendly cleric, if there's one available.

2)a summonded defense command that actually is incredibly strong on
behavior so you can force your team to stick together.  Good old
strengths in numbers.

3)if you can create an explosion big enough to put a crater on the
planet, damn it, you shouldn't have to run away from the explosion.
